column2: A Card for All Seasons
What you'll do
Use your knowledge of HTML and CSS to create a webpage that can work as a poster or greeting card.
See you later!

Hey, {{user_name}}, you’ve learned the basics of HTML and CSS already - so let's use those skills to make a poster. You can use this technique to create posters for lots of different occasions, like holidays, birthdays, graduations, whatever you like!
Like our previous HTML adventures, if the previewer page doesn't open, try opening your browser or clicking this link: https://codepen.io/madetohack/pen/abzNgQe?editors=1100

Ok, let's take a minute to look over the code in the HTML and CSS sections. The code in the HTML section is the basic skeleton we'll use for this project, and the code in the CSS section includes the basic style.
Let’s start with the text-align property in the CSS section. What do you think happens when you change the word center to left or right? Give it a try, and see if your prediction was right!
When you're done, change the text-align property back to center.

Great! Now, let’s give the poster some color. Within the div brackets ( {} ), add a new line and type the following: background: yellow; If you did it right, the background of the <div> should now be yellow.

Let’s try adding some flair to the edges of your card - Check out the border property in the div section. Right now, it's 2px solid black. What happens if we change it to... 4px dotted green? Let's do it!
Nice! Try adding this property too: border-radius: 40px;
Wow! It looks like your poster is starting to take shape.
Hmm, I can't make out what the image is. Try changing the width of the div to 400px.
That's still pretty unclear. What do you think we should do about that? What happens if you replace width: 400px; with max-width:100%; ?

The window is as big as it can get, and the image still isn't right, darn. Well, we can't just leave it like that. Maybe we need to tweak the image itself? There's always more than one way to solve a problem!
Let's fix that image, and to do that, we need to add some CSS that defines properties for the <img> tag, which stands for... you guessed it, image.
Add a few lines under the closing bracket ( } ) of the div section, and add the following: img { }
Let’s add a new property into the img tag: max-width: 75%; This property says "this image can only be as wide as 75% of the page, at most."
That image is looking a little tight against the border, so let's fix that by adding some padding in the img section - check the div CSS for clues.
As you can see in the div CSS, you'd want to add padding: 10px; in the img section. Make a new line under the max-width section, and write it there.
Perfect. Your cookie should now fit comfortably inside the poster. No matter how you resize the window, the cookie should be nice and snug - test it out!
Now, let's style the h1 tags. Add a new entry in the CSS pane, under the image CSS: h1 { }
To change h1's font, we need to add some code between those curly braces: font-family: Impact; and then on the next line, font-size: 50pt;
Check out how your text changed. Cool, right? But... do you see that weird space there, between the h1 and h3 text? Let's fix that.

Add margin: 10px; into your h1 CSS, and that should do it. Remember, if you're trying to fix a problem in CSS, you can do it by adjusting the problem tag, or your can just adjust the tags that interact with the problem tag. Think laterally!
Let's get even fancier! Try adding this to your h1 CSS: text-decoration: underline;
Sweeeet. What do think might happen if you tried adding overline to text-decoration: underline; ? Give it a shot, try text-decoration: underline overline;
Weird, right? Speaking of weird, what do you think would happen if you created a CSS section for the h4 tag, and added color: #181866;?
Yep, nothing. There's no h4 content on the page!
Alright, here we are at the final steps. Add your own message to the poster!
Way to go! You've created your first poster!

If you want to try some advanced practice: Try changing the style of the text on your own. Start by using the name of the color, like color: green;, and then use a hex color code. When you're done with that, try adding additional styles like bold or italics. It's gonna look awesome!
Take a screenshot of your poster and share it with your family and friends! If you share it online, don't forget to tag the Hack team with the hashtag #MadeToHack. See you on the internet!
